description: From Old French solas, from Latin sōlācium (“consolation”), root from Proto-Indo-European *selh₂- (“mercy, comfort”).

entries.meaning: Comfort or consolation in a time of loneliness or distress.
examples: You cannot put a monetary value on emotional solace.

entries.meaning: A source of comfort or consolation.
examples: The proper solaces of age are not music and compliments, but wisdom and devotion.

verbs.description: solace (third-person singular simple present solaces, present participle solacing, simple past and past participle solaced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give solace to; comfort; cheer; console.
(intransitive) To take comfort; to be cheered.
